source.bf7ff82d:
# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session
source.96c03291:
#Importing libraries. 
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import plotly.express as px
low_memory=False
source.b7034fc5:
#adding datetime using pd.to_datetime function
df['year']=df['mp_month'].astype(str)+'/'+df['mp_year'].astype(str)
df['year'] = pd.to_datetime(df.year, format='%m/%Y' )
source.db5b42cc:
#I am creating a dataset to work with. 
a=df[['adm0_name', 'cm_name', 'cur_name', 'mp_price','year', 'adm0_id' ]]
a['mm']=a['cur_name']
source.a9dccb1c:
#We are converting String values to integer. 
#And filling missing values 
a['mm']=a.mm.replace(to_replace ="NIS",
                 value ='NaN')
a['mm']=a.mm.replace(to_replace ="MGA",
                 value ='NaN')
a['mm'].fillna(method="pad")
source.92fee5c1:
#I am creating a scatter chart for Global Food Prices trend after converting
#the values in USD to get the most accurate result. 
fig = px.scatter(data_frame=a,  x="year", y="mm", color='cm_name', trendline='lowess', 
                 title='Prices(USD) over time in the World' )

fig.show()
source.126b6cee:
#Creating a column for numnbers of data for each country.
df2=df[['adm0_name',]]
df2['Counts'] = np.zeros(len(df2))
df2 = df2.groupby(['adm0_name']).count()
df2['Countries']=df2.index
source.97322806:
fig = px.bar(data_frame=df2,  x='Countries', y='Counts', color='Countries' ,width=1000,
    height=500, title='Most data sets by countries')


fig.show()
source.453ece79:
#z is an example of a data set to find a global trend for only Bread prices
z = a[(a["cm_name"] == 'Bread - Retail')]
source.de71fc6b:
fig = px.area(data_frame=z,  x=z["year"], y= z["mm"],color='adm0_name',
                 title='Bread prices(USD) trend in the World', )

fig.show()
source.f0d29c9b:
fig = px.density_heatmap(data_frame=z,  x=z["year"], y= z["mm"],
                 title='Bread prices(USD) heatmap chart', )

fig.show()
source.435a8bcf:
fig = px.violin(data_frame=z,  x=z["year"], y= z["mm"], color='adm0_name',
                 title='Bread prices(USD) colored by countries using Violin chart', )

fig.show()
source.f55636e5:
#df1 will be our data frame to create charts for each country with the data sets it was provided.
df1 = df[["cm_name","cur_name","mp_price","year"]]
source.81600062:
AFN = df1[df1['cur_name'].isin(["AFN"])]
AFN['mp_priceusd'] = (AFN['mp_price'] * 0.011)


fig = px.scatter(data_frame=AFN,  x=AFN["year"], y= AFN["mp_priceusd"], color='cm_name' ,trendline="lowess", 
                 title='Prices(USD) over time in Afghanistan', )

fig.show()

source.d884ae84: If you like this project, please support with an upvote and feel free to comment. Thanks
source.c9879698:
Hi Everyone, 
I am going to work with the data set of 'Global Food Prices' updated on kaggle by @lasaljaywardena. 

I want to organize the dataset and visualize the trend of global food prices. 

As a beginner Data scientist, I am excited to work with new datasets to find trends and get meaningful insights. 

I am hoping to improve my programming skills and helpiong you to learn something from my project.
source.e7b2be0a: The result of this heatmap chart showing us that the most common price for a bread is $0.25 - $0.30
source.1e344a8b: I liked this chart because we can actually analyze the price of a Bread with min and max prices inluding mean and median prices.
